body: The New York metropolitan region came out of the deep freeze yesterday and rapidly regained its customary, businesslike stride after the long Christmas holiday. But with the warming weather came warnings of another drenching and flooded, rather then icy, roadways. The low temperature of 16 degrees yesterday was recorded just after midnight, and the
title: AFTER THE COLD, CITY GETS BACK TO NORMAL PACE

body: Former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn was found guilty yesterday of forgery and conspiracy charges stemming from his unsuccessful effort to reverse his defeat in a 1982 Congressional primary. He was convicted of having led a scheme to forge signatures on hundreds of voter registration cards at the Brooklyn offices of the Board of
title: BEATTY IS GUILTY OF A CONSPIRACY IN VOTE FORGERY

body: Two gypsy-cab drivers were found shot to death early yesterday in different neighborhoods of Brooklyn, the police said. The first victim, Joseph St. Louis, 45 years old, of Brooklyn, was found at 12:55 A.M., slumped over the steering wheel of his cab, parked at 29 Lefferts Place in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section. Mr. St. Louis, who worked for a
title: THE CITY; 2 Cabbies Found Slain in Brooklyn

body: Gretchen Maie Price, daughter of Mrs. William Louis Huber of Sag Harbor, L.I., and the late George Arthur Price of Victoria, Va., was married yesterday to Alan John Rude, son of Alan Gregory Rude of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., and the late Bea Bernadette Downey Rude. The Rev. Thomas Dix Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal
title: GretchenM.Price WedtoAlanRude

body: In his office at Police Headquarters - amid color-coded charts of criminal conspiracies and city maps that show even alleyways and building configurations - Capt. Arthur Katz keeps a quote from Jonathan Swift: ''Laws are like cobwebs, which may catch small flies, but let wasps and hornets break through.'' Swift's sentiment is widely shared among
title: STEMMING THE TIDE OF STOLEN GOODS: MANY IDEAS BUT LITTLE OVERALL STRATEGY

body: A Baptist nursing home in Brooklyn said yesterday that it would admit a patient suffering from acquired immune deficiency syndrome, thus becoming the first nursing home in New York City to accept an AIDS victim. The decision is regarded by public health authorities as significant because many AIDS victims rejected by their families and then by
title: NURSING HOME PLANS TO ADMIT VICTIM OF AIDS

body: When Rose Brush owned her house, the walls were falling apart, the front steps and interior stairs were crumbling with age, the water heater was worn out, the windows were drafty and the gas company was threatening to shut off service for nonpayment. Although there were was no mortgage, Mrs. Brush found that with income of $900 a month, medical
title: PROBLEMS PERSIST WHEN CITY OWNS HOUSES

body: A gunman being chased by two plainclothes policemen in Brooklyn was shot to death early yesterday after he wounded an officer, the police said. The gunman, Clyde Sedney, 21 years old, of the East New York section of Brooklyn, died at Brookdale Hospital shortly before 1 A.M., according to Capt. Jack Clark of the 75th Precinct. The incident occurred
title: Brooklyn Man Shot to Death AfterWoundingPoliceOfficer

body: THE year 1983 is establishing itself as the period in which single-family houses built in a factory and assembled on large development tracts were delivered to New Yorkers for the first time. The scale is modest in comparison with what is believed to be the market potential, and with the construction of ''stick-built'' houses - those built on the
title: THE FACTORY-BUILT HOUSE GETS A FOOTHOLD IN CITY

body: Twenty-two years ago, Dwayne Lee Gosso was born into the custody of New York State, the son of a prison inmate who did not want him. For two decades he was a child of the state bureaucracy, living in foundling and foster homes, mental hospitals and rehabilitation centers. Along the way, according to his lawyer, he was diagnosed as mildly retarded
title: LONG, TROUBLED ODYSSEY OF A CHILD OF BUREAUCRACY

body: Manufactured housing is making its appearance in a widening spectrum of new single-family buildings across the city. At the same time, talks aimed at establishing facilities to do the construction within city limits are intensifying. So far, public attention has focused on the use of mobile homes trucked to the Bronx in two sections from a plant in
title: About Real Estate; Manufactured Housing Moves Into City

body: As the Board of Education's new all-day kindergartens begin their second month, the widely hailed program is nonetheless troubled by overcrowding and equipment shortages in some areas of New York City, officials in those areas say. Over all, the program has generated more praise than criticism. Indeed, the all-day kindergartens - previously
title: Popularity Breeding Problems In New All-Day Kindergartens

body: The owner of a Haitian newspaper published in New York City, who had reported death threats because of his criticism of the Haitian regime, was shot to death Wednesday night outside his Brooklyn home, the police said yesterday. The detective in charge of the case said that ''right now it's 50-50 whether this is a political assassination or a
title: OWNER OF NEWSPAPER FOR HAITIAN EMIGRES IS SLAIN IN BROOKLYN

body: A 77-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested after he used a pistol to capture a 21-year-old man who he asserted had robbed him last March, the police said. The older man, James Bowman, was held on a gun-possession charge, and his captive, Alfonso Thomas, was charged with robbery, according to Capt. James Marcus of the Housing Authority police. The
title: THE CITY; Man Who Caught 'Mugger' Is Seized

body: I HATE the fact that I can see that rock. It should be buried in the ground -- it belongs in the soil. Its home is with the roots of trees, not thrown on my lawn to be carted away with garbage. Progress, the future, they call it, building on every square inch of green. Making way for 44 large new quarter-million-dollar homes. What's the harm done
title: They Call It Progress

body: A city bus driver who shot himself, possibly accidentally, while driving his bus through Brooklyn was arrested yesterday for having the gun and for reporting that he had been shot from outside the bus, officials said. Edward Silberfarb, a spokesman for the Transit Authority police, said the driver, Michael Rothstein, 27 years old, had been charged
title: THE CITY; Bus Driver Shoots Himself on Job

body: Thunderstorms dropped more than two inches of rain on New York City in four hours last night, knocking out service on almost half the subway system and causing scattered power failures and widespread flooding. The flooding caused delays of up to several hours at airports and extensive traffic jams on highways. Fierce gusts of wind blew off tree
title: 2-INCH RAIN FALL IN 4 HOURS CAUSES PARTIAL SHUTDOWN OF THE SUBWAYS

body: A badly burned body found last Thursday in the air shaft of an abandoned building in Brooklyn has been identified as that of Baila Mayerfeld, a member of Community Board 9 in the Crown Heights section of the borough. Miss Mayerfeld, who was 44 years old, had been last seen near her apartment at 682 Eastern Parkway, three days before her body was
title: THE CITY; Body of Woman Is Identified

body: The East New York section of Brooklyn will be the target of a twoyear, $120,000 crime-prevention program announced yesterday by the New York City Partnership and the Eisenhower Foundation for the Prevention of Violence. During August, 500 residents and owners of businesses in the area will be interviewed at random to find out what they perceive as
title: CRIME FIGHT AIMS AT BROOKLYN

body: Governor Cuomo went to Brooklyn last night to tell church leaders that the state would provide $7.5 million in low-interest mortgages to spur a housing and commercial redevelopment plan. Mr. Cuomo met at Public School 55, at Bergen Street and Hopkinson Avenue, with leaders of the East Brooklyn Churches, representing 40 churches in the Ocean
title: Cuomo and Church Leaders Meet in Brooklyn on Housing

body: In Washington Heights in Manhattan, jobs have been found for 100 people. In the East New York section of Brooklyn, an anticrime program has reduced burglaries in the East Brooklyn Industrial Park. In Jamaica, Queens, owners of businesses say they feel better about their location because of extra security patrols and sanitation crews. On White
title: PRIVATE GROUPS LEND NEIGHBORHOODS A HAND

body: Since early June, an exhibition on housing development in the city over the last 170 years has been on display, and to specialists in the housing field it has an interest that goes beyond the visual. The exhibit is called ''At Home in the City: Housing in New York, 1810-1983.'' It was conceived by Roy Strickland and James Sanders, principals in the
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; EXHIBIT ON GROWTH OF NEW YORK AS A CITY OF RENTERS

body: Patricia Bradley Murray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Murray of New Canaan, Conn., was married in Darien, Conn., yesterday to Peter B. Derr, son of the Rev. Virginia Bush Derr of Rochester and the Rev. Dr. Thomas Sieger Derr of Northampton, Mass. The Rev. D. Bradley Murray, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman
title: Patricia Murray Married in Darien

body: From the time he purchased his first racquet, for $2.99 when he was 13 years old, Jose Rodriguez figured that tennis could be the way out of his East New York, Brooklyn, neighborhood and into college. But the 17-year-old graduating senior from Bushwick High School knows that tennis is no shortcut, not when he has to walk an hour and a half each day
title: SCOUTING; No Shortcuts

body: Percentage of students in the classes of 1973, 1978 and 1982 in New York City public high schools who have completed three years or more of ''academic'' courses in English and two years or more in math by the end of their junior year. N.A.= Data incomplete or unavailable Asterisk denotes schools that have programs requiring special application for
title: HOW ENROLLMENT IN HIGH SCHOOL MATH AND ENGLISH HAS CHANGED IN 10 YEARS

body: THIS weekend, with warm weather at last more than a rumor, the metropolitan area heads determinedly into the festival season. Not that all festivals are outdoors; they just seem to germinate best in fine weather. So from clowns in Chelsea to dance on an East River pier, from a marathon of comedy to a marathon by women of jazz, from folk music in
title: A FESTIVAL OF FESTIVALS, INDOORS AND OUT

body: Sister Betty Nickels is a short, sturdy woman who sometimes talks like a social worker and sometimes talks like a street kid. She doesn't have much money, and she doesn't have much privacy. She eats a lot of spaghetti for dinner, and she isn't sure of the last time she had steak. When the Federal Government was giving out cheese, she ate meat loaf
title: ABOUT NEW YORK

body: In front of a house on Lafayette Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant stands a magnolia tree as big as a brownstone, its broad leaves as glossy as if each had been individually oiled. It is a magnolia grandiflora, and it usually grows nowhere north of the Mason-Dixon line. Somehow, improbably, with considerable help from human beings, this tree grows in
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; CITY OR BOROUGH, DODGERS OR NO DODGERS, BROOKLYN IS BROOKLYN

body: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy who shot himself in the head in what the police believe was a game of Russian roulette died yesterday, authorities said. The boy, Jason Ost, died at 10:30 P.M. at Brookdale Hospital Medical Center. The incident occurred at 10 P.M. Thursday, as the boy and his stepbrother, Lee Bock, 16, were playing in their home at 1230
title: A Brooklyn Boy Dies Of Self-Inflicted Shot

body: NEARLY a decade ago, residents of the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, seeking to rebuild the area's d evastated housing stock, won Federal and New York City approval of t heir plan to renovate 450 apartments in a block of Howard Avenue forl ow- and moderate-income residents. But the rehabilitation plan for the apartments, named the Eliot Graham
title: ...AS APARTMENTS NEAR FINISH

body: Ten people were arrested when detectives raided four apartments at 300 Fifth Avenue in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn at 7:30 A.M. yesterday. Three pounds of heroin and cocaine were found, along with four handguns, two shotguns and a rifle. Augustini Luna, 46 years old, who was said by the police to be the ring's leader, and the nine others
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: Rabbi Morris M. Rose, former leader of congregations in Brooklyn and Queens, and in Morgantown, W.Va., died of a stroke Saturday at University Hospital. He was 85 years old, and lived in Kew Gardens, Queens. From 1929 to 1951, Rabbi Rose was the leader of Temple Sinai in the East New York section of Brooklyn. He then became leader of the Tree of
title: RABBI MORRIS M. ROSE

body: ON a small lot in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section, a project i s under way that will restore four simple 19th-century wooden h ouses to their original appearance. The houses, on a lot on Bergen Street between Buffalo and Rochester Avenues in a scarred and blighted neighborhood, are both New York City and national landmarks. They are also the
title: BROOKLYN RESTORATION RECALLS BLACK HISTORY

body: A 16-year-old Brooklyn boy was arrested yesterday and charged with robbery in the $1,900 holdup of the driver of a soft-drink delivery truck in Cypress Hills, Queens, on Friday, the police said. Another youth involved in the robbery later shot and wounded a police officer before being arrested, according to the police. The officer is in fair
title: Teen-ager Held in Robbery

body: For 11 New Yorkers this weekend, death came by bullet, by knife, by baseball bat and by hammer. The number killed was not a record; it was close to average in a city that had 1,675 murders last year and 1,832 the year before. Like Roberta Kaplan, stabbed to death in her Greenwich Village shop Friday, some of the weekend victims were slain by
title: A WEEKEND'S TOLL IN NEW YORK CITY: 11 MURDERS

body: The police said last night that they had arrested two men in connection with a series of robberies in SoHo in the last two months in which one victim was raped and another was sexually abused. They said the men were charged with robbing and raping one victim and were being questioned about the other robberies. The suspects, who were arrested at
title: TWO MEN ARE ARRESTED IN SOHO RAPE AND ROBBERY

body: Two children died yesterday after apparently becoming trapped in a refrigerator in the basement of their home in Brooklyn, the police said. The two children, Elick Davis, 3 years old, of 337 Pennsylvania Avenue in the East New York section, and his sister, Janneatha, 2, were reported missing by their mother, Mintrous Davis, during the afternoon.
title: 2 Children Found Smothered In a Refrigerator in Brooklyn

body: Some people waiting for buses will swear drivers aim for the slush puddles as they pull into a stop. Or that they like to close doors on old people trying to catch a bus. Or prefer to keep their bus's destination a secret from people seeking directions. These situations - and what to do about them - were among the topics discussed around a table by
title: NEW YORK'S BUS DRIVERS TAUGHT TO GRIN AND BEAR IT

body: Civic Honors S ister Betty Nickels remembers the 17-year-old Chinese girl of ''genius mentality'' who ran away from home because her parents expected her to support them and produce faultless grades. Another girl, whose parents had died, wanted to escape her sister's crowded house. Other girls were fleeing years of physical abuse. ''There are so
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: As construction of the city's first satellite earth station proceeds in the East New York section of Brooklyn, residents of that community are debating whether the facility will automatically trigger needed revitalization of the area or whether its owner should provide direct subsidies for renewal. The owner of the station is Hughes Communications
title: SATELLITE STATION SPURS BROOKLYN DEBATE

body: A 3-year-old boy was killed yesterday when he darted out from between two parked cars and was crushed by a fire truck on its way to a blaze in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said. An assistant fire commissioner, John Mulligan, said a firefighter riding alongside the driver had first noticed the boy running on the sidewalk. ''The
title: THE CITY; Fire Truck Kills Boy, 3, in Brooklyn

body: Although homeowners in Howard Beach, Queens, still shake their heads in disbelief as they recall the predawn crime rampage five weeks ago in which a gang of shotgun-wielding youths terrorized their neighborhood, some are resisting calls to arm themselves for protection. The other night, more than 100 residents of Howard Beach and nearby
title: CALL TO ARM IN THE HOME IS DEBATED

body: 'Taste of the Big Apple' I t opens with a full-throttle soundtrack of ''I Guess the Lord Must Be in New York City.'' In sun-drenched color it zips rhapsodically for 20 minutes through 250 locales - peopled, it would appear, largely by celebrities. The promotional movie is ''Taste of the Big Apple,'' aimed at anybody with a case of those little-town
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Frederick W. Eversley Jr., a civil engineer and founder and former president of what was once one of the largest construction businesses with minority-group ownership in the New York area, died of a heart attack last Wednesday while swimming at his vacation home on Nassau, the Bahamas. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan. At its height
title: F.W. EVERSLEY JR., CONTRACTOR, DEAD

body: Following are the scores, released by the New York City Board of Education, on the reading tests given in city's public elementary schools and junior high schools in April 1982. The center column shows the proportion of pupils in each school reading at or above grade level; the right-hand column gives each school's overall city-wide ranking.
title: Scores on Reading Tests Given in Public Schools
